message.content:
Deep research on HARDMAXXING surgical procedures for facial enhancement. Search for:

1. **Jaw surgeries** - BSSO, genioplasty, jaw angle implants, V-line surgery
2. **Midface surgeries** - Le Fort, cheek implants, midface lift
3. **Rhinoplasty** - types, costs, recovery, revision rates
4. **Eye surgeries** - canthoplasty, blepharoplasty, orbital decompression
5. **Lip procedures** - lip lift, lip fillers
6. **Bone surgeries** - custom implants, PEEK vs silicone vs Medpor

For each surgery document:
- Average cost (USA, Turkey, Korea)
- Recovery time
- Risk level
- Expected improvement (in PSL/harmony points)
- Best surgeons mentioned
- Red flags and complications

Search Looksmax surgery threads, RealSelf, plastic surgery subreddits.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about jaw angle implants, comparing custom vs. standard options, costs, and surgeon considerations:

## Cost Comparison: Custom vs. Standard Jaw Implants

### Standard (Off-the-Shelf) Jaw Implants
- Most jaw implants cost between $2,000 and $4,000.
- The most common approach is to use three separate implants, including off-the-shelf chin and jaw angle implants placed through submental and intraoral incisions. That total cost averages around $8,500 to $9,500.
- The average cost of jaw implants depends on whether it's a custom implant or regular implant. The average range is from $8,000 to $15,000.

### Custom Jaw Implants
- The custom approach uses a one-piece implant that is made off of a 3D CT scan taken from the patient. It is completely customized to the patient's jaw anatomy and aesthetic desires. That total cost is in the range of about $15,000.
- A custom jawline implant that includes the entire jawline from chin back to the jaw angles will cost in the range of $12,000 to $14,000 for all costs involved.
- Custom-fit chin implants are personalized implants made using 3D imaging and molds of the patient's chin and jawline. They offer the most precise fit and contour. Custom implants are smart for patients with unique facial features. Costs start at $3,400 but vary based on your treatment plan.

## Custom vs. Standard: Key Differences

Prefabricated jaw implants are limited in the changes they can make. They by nature cannot be created with the patient's unique facial structure in mind. A prefabricated implant is more difficult to manipulate in terms of the shape of the face. This is particularly a concern for patients seeking reconstructive work following trauma, previous surgery/implants or serious facial injury.(no content)In contrast, custom-made jaw implants resolve these issues. Since each implant is made according to patient specifications and balanced with precision computer software, the final results can be incredibly close to what you envisioned and are contoured to the underlying bone.

## Factors Affecting Cost
Prices vary greatly because the surgery itself encompasses a wide range of techniques that can be performed to different extents. The recommendation is to first find the most qualified surgeons where you want the surgery performed that are board certified by the American Board of Plastic Surgery.(no content)Your individual quote will include the surgeon's fee, anesthesia costs, facility fees for the operating room and all other supplies and implants needed. Your fees also include all your follow-up appointments.(no content)Prices tend to be higher in major metro areas on the East and West coasts.

## Insurance Coverage
Elective chin augmentation isn't covered by health insurance. But reconstructive cases may receive partial or full coverage.

Here's what I found about BSSO jaw surgery costs and recovery:

## What is BSSO?

A Bilateral Sagittal Split Osteotomy (BSSO) is a type of jaw surgery where the lower jaw is separated from the face and repositioned.(no content)This surgery is performed entirely inside the mouth so there is no visible scar on the face.(no content)BSSO is the most common technique, allowing surgeons to move the lower jaw forward or backward.

## Costs (2024-2025)

**United States (Manhattan):**
- Lower jaw surgery (mandibular osteotomy) addresses underbites, facial asymmetry, and other lower jaw issues. Manhattan pricing for these procedures typically ranges from $20,000 to $35,000.
- For patients with more complex jaw misalignments affecting both jaws, bimaxillary osteotomy (also called double jaw surgery) may be necessary. This combined procedure typically costs between $35,000 and $45,000 in Manhattan.

**Europe:**
- In France, one user paid 3500 euros for a Bimax including 6mm LeFort I and 12mm BSSO (6-7 degrees of CCW rotation).
- One user reported a final cost estimate in Germany of 8.5k for Bimax in a major city from a surgeon who is a Fellow of the European Board of Oral-Maxillo-Facial Surgery.
- In Poland, bimax costs about 4-5k euros.

**Italy (Popular "looksmax" surgeons):**
- Pagnoni has already reached the 33k range.
- Some predict that in two years you will not be able to get jaw surgery for under 30k in Italy at the well-known forum surgeons.

## Recovery

The BSSO can produce a lot of swelling. If the BSSO is combined with a surgery to the upper jaw, such as a Le Fort I, you will have even more swelling. The swelling should peak after 2-3 days and can be dramatic.(no content)It may be difficult to speak or drink normally. Most of the swelling will resolve after about 2 weeks.(no content)This surgery takes 2 to 3 hours.(no content)Patients who undergo a BSSO procedure typically spend 1 night in the hospital.(no content)Your orthodontic care will continue after surgery. This can take the form of rubber band therapy to help guide the lower jaw into the upper jaw. Braces may also continue for several months after the surgery.

Links: [{"title":"Le Fort I Guide: Procedure, Recovery, and More – myFace","url":"https://www.myface.org/surgeries/le-fort-1/"},{"title":"Le Fort I osteotomy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Le_Fort_I_osteotomy"},{"title":"Le Fort 1 Osteotomy: A Comprehensive Guide to Upper Jaw Surgery","url":"https://drlarrywolford.com/le-fort-1-osteotomy-a-comprehensive-guide-to-upper-jaw-surgery/"},{"title":"Le Fort Osteotomy (Maxillary Osteotomy) - MD Searchlight","url":"https://mdsearchlight.com/surgical/le-fort-osteotomy-maxillary-osteotomy/"},{"title":"Le Fort Osteotomy - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf","url":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK564372/"},{"title":"An Update on Midface Advancement Using Le Fort II and III Distraction Osteogenesis - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4219913/"},{"title":"LeFort I Osteotomy - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3805729/"},{"title":"Le Fort Procedure for Malocclusion | North Carolina Specialty Hospital","url":"https://www.ncspecialty.com/blog/le-fort-surgery/"},{"title":"Le Fort 3 Osteotomy | Hospitaprime Clinic","url":"https://hospitaprime.com/en/maxillofacial-surgery/le-fort-3-osteotomy/"},{"title":"Le Fort 2 Osteotomy | Hospitaprime Clinic","url":"https://hospitaprime.com/maxillofacial-surgery/le-fort-2-osteotomy/"}]

Here's what I found about Le Fort midface surgery, including information on recovery and complications from 2024 sources:

## Le Fort Osteotomy Overview

The LeFort I osteotomy is a procedure utilized extensively within the field of oral and maxillofacial surgery when maxilla repositioning is required to correct dentofacial abnormalities or facilitate surgical access.(no content)The Le Fort I osteotomy is a surgical procedure to realign the upper jaw (maxilla), primarily performed to fix deformities of the face and jaw, improve facial aesthetics, treat malocclusions (misaligned teeth), and treat certain medical conditions, such as obstructive sleep apnea.

## Recovery Timeline

**Le Fort I:**
- The swelling should peak after 2-3 days and can be dramatic. Most of the swelling will resolve after about 2 weeks.
- Most of the discomfort you will experience after the surgery will be from the swelling of the face rather than the pain from the surgery itself. You will receive medicine to help with discomfort.
- Cool compresses to the face and sleeping with the face raised above the heart will also help decrease the swelling. Lip moisturizer is recommended to prevent drying of the lips.

**Le Fort II:**
- Most patients return to normal activities within 6-8 weeks, but full recovery, including bone healing, may take several months.

**Le Fort III:**
- Most patients can return to normal activities within 8-12 weeks, but full recovery, including bone healing and orthodontic adjustments, may take several months to a year.

## Complications

Anatomical complications include nasal septum deviation, nonunion (failure of the bone to heal properly), and malposition of the maxilla. Vascular complications primarily involve hemorrhage. Ischemic complications, such as avascular necrosis (bone death) are also possible.(no content)The complications of Le Fort Osteotomy include complications related to the body's anatomy, infections, blood supply disruptions, blood vessel problems, nerve disorders, and ear complications.

**For Le Fort II specifically:**
Potential risks include infection, nerve damage, bone relapse, and sinus or nasal issues. These risks are minimized with proper surgical care and follow-up.(no content)Temporary or permanent changes in sensation around the midface and nose may occur due to nerve involvement during the surgery. Most sensory changes are temporary and improve with time. In rare cases, the repositioned bones may shift back toward their original position, a condition known as relapse.(no content)However, these complications are exceedingly rare. The relative safety, versatility, and technical simplicity of the LeFort I osteotomy contribute to its position as a workhorse in maxillofacial surgery.

## Cost Information

The search results did not include specific cost information for Le Fort surgery. Costs can vary significantly based on the type of procedure (Le Fort I, II, or III), geographic location, surgeon experience, hospital fees, and whether the surgery is covered by insurance for functional purposes. You may want to consult directly with oral and maxillofacial surgeons for cost estimates.

Here's what I found about genioplasty (sliding chin surgery) costs and information for the USA, Korea, and Turkey:

## Costs by Country

### USA
The average cost of chin augmentation (mentoplasty) is $3,641, according to the American Society of Plastic Surgeons. This average cost is only part of the total price – it does not include anesthesia, operating room facilities, or other related expenses.(no content)Chin implant surgery (genioplasty) costs around $3,000 to $10,000. You'll also need to pay extra for anesthesia and the hospital room. It usually costs between $5,000 - $10,000. That price tag may not cover the doctor's fee, anesthesia, and any materials they use.(no content)The same procedure in the United States and the UK can cost up to $20,000.

### Korea
The average cost of V shape jaw surgery (which can include sliding genioplasty) in Korea ranges from $6,000 to $15,000 USD, depending on the surgeon, the clinic, the technique, and the extent of the correction.(no content)The cost usually includes the consultation fee, the anesthesia fee, the hospital fee, the surgery fee, and the post-operative care fee. However, it may not include the cost of additional procedures, such as chin augmentation, cheekbone reduction, or fat grafting, which can increase the total cost by $2,000 to $5,000 USD each. Travel expenses can add up to $2,000 to $4,000 USD for a two-week stay.

### Turkey
The cost of genioplasty in Turkey is approximately $3,000 to $5,000.(no content)Chin augmentation costs in Turkey are 50–70% lower than in Western countries, without compromising on quality.(no content)Clinics in Turkey often offer comprehensive packages covering cost of surgery, accommodation, airport transfers, and even post-surgery consultations. All-inclusive packages make the process seamless and stress-free for international patients.

## About the Procedure

Sliding genioplasty is a chin enhancement surgery that advances the chin bone forward to improve facial balance and profile definition without the use of implants. A doctor will recommend this procedure if the patient has a retruded chin and profile is not defined.(no content)The results of genioplasty are permanent. However, as with any cosmetic surgery, the natural aging process can still affect the appearance of your chin over time.

## Results & Recovery

The final result of chin surgery will not be visible for several months as the swelling completely disappears and the tissues heal. However, you will notice a significant improvement in facial harmony and profile within the first few days. Swelling and bruising gradually diminish over the next 10 to 15 days. Final bone consolidation after bone remodeling generally takes 6 weeks.(no content)Patients often report a noticeable improvement in facial balance and harmony post-genioplasty. Viewing before and after photos can give you an idea of what to expect.

## Risks

The risks of genioplasty surgery may include but are not limited to infection, bruising, asymmetry, swelling and numbness in the operated area.

Sliding genioplasty is a chin enhancement surgery that advances the chin bone forward to improve facial balance and profile definition without the use of implants. A doctor will recommend this procedure if the patient has a retruded chin and profile is not defined.(no content)The results of genioplasty are permanent. However, as with any cosmetic surgery, the natural aging process can still affect the appearance of your chin over time.

## Results & Recovery

The final result of chin surgery will not be visible for several months as the swelling completely disappears and the tissues heal. However, you will notice a significant improvement in facial harmony and profile within the first few days. Swelling and bruising gradually diminish over the next 10 to 15 days. Final bone consolidation after bone remodeling generally takes 6 weeks.(no content)Patients often report a noticeable improvement in facial balance and harmony post-genioplasty. Viewing before and after photos can give you an idea of what to expect.

## Risks

The risks of genioplasty surgery may include but are not limited to infection, bruising, asymmetry, swelling and numbness in the operated area.

Based on my search results, here's what I found about cheek implants (malar/midface) costs and surgeons for 2024:

## Cost of Cheek Implants

The average cost of cheek implants (malar augmentation) is $3,876, according to the latest statistics from the American Society of Plastic Surgeons.(no content)This average cost is only part of the total price – it does not include anesthesia, operating room facilities or other related expenses.

According to a 2024 study by CareCredit:
- The national average cost for a cheek implant procedure with both malar and submalar implants in the United States is $8,795, but it can vary between $6,960 and $15,872 depending on factors such as location, other procedures that might be involved or post-surgery care. The average cost of malar implants alone is $4,453, and the average cost of submalar implants alone is $4,710.
- This cost information is based on research in the 50 United States and the District of Columbia, which was conducted by ASQ360° in 2024 on behalf of Synchrony's CareCredit.(no content)The average cost of cheek implants depends on whether it's a custom implant or regular implant. The average range is from $7,000 to $11,000.(no content)The average cost of cheek or chin implants may range anywhere between $6,000 and $12,000, depending on various factors. The costs of anesthesia and operating room may or may not be included in this price.

## Types of Cheek Implants

Malar implants are placed directly on top of your natural cheekbones. This procedure gives you more projection of the cheekbones, like the high-cheekbone look you might see on models.(no content)Submalar implants round out a sunken or hollowed appearance of the cheeks to provide more balance and support to the midface.(no content)The cheekbones and cheeks are both augmented using a combination implant. Some patients may choose to have both operations done at the same time if their cheekbones aren't well-shaped and their midface has lost fullness.

## Factors Affecting Cost

A surgeon's fee for cheek augmentation will be based on his or her experience, the type of procedure used and the geographic office location.(no content)Providers who practice in major cities with a high cost of living, like New York and LA, tend to have higher overhead. If cost is a major consideration, you may find that you can save a lot of money by finding a qualified, well-reviewed surgeon who practices in a modest practice within your metro area or a more affordable city.

## Choosing a Surgeon

It's especially important to choose a board-certified facial plastic surgeon who frequently performs this procedure and has a track record of positive patient reviews.(no content)When choosing a board-certified plastic surgeon for cheek augmentation, remember that the surgeon's experience and your comfort with him or her are just as important as the final cost of the surgery.(no content)Many plastic surgeons offer patient financing plans for cheek augmentation.

Based on my search results, here's what I found about canthoplasty eye surgery:

## Cost

Canthoplasty costs $6,398 on average, though the cost can range from $1,081 to $11,999, according to 48 reviews from RealSelf members who've had the procedure.(no content)The national average cost of a canthoplasty fox eye surgery is $6,702, but costs can range from $5,173 to $10,993.(no content)However, costs range from just over $1,000 to more than $10,000. Various factors will influence how much you pay for canthoplasty surgery.

From Looksmax discussions, one user reported paying $2,000 for lateral canthoplasty, $5,500 for endoscopic lateral browlift, $8,500 for standard Medpor infraorbital rim implants, and $2,000 for fat grafting to the periorbital area.

## Results

Canthoplasty surgery can make your eyes appear larger and brighter, with a cat or "fox eye" shape. It can give eyes with a negative canthal tilt (a genetically downturned appearance) a happier or more awake look.(no content)The final results will become apparent after a few months.

From Looksmax perspectives, some users note that "canthoplasty ALONE can ONLY raise your PCT [positive canthal tilt]: however, this is NOT reliable. A lot of reports that the outer canthus then still drops after some time."

## Complications

Every surgery involves risk; however, serious complications from a canthoplasty are extremely rare. Swelling and bruising are common during the first few weeks post-operatively, and you may also experience dry eyes, excess tearing, and blurred vision.(no content)As with any surgical procedure, canthoplasty carries potential risks, including infection, bleeding, scarring, asymmetry, and unsatisfactory aesthetic results. Specific to eyelid surgery, there is also a risk of dry eyes, impaired eyelid function, or excessive tightening leading to discomfort or difficulty closing the eyes fully. Rare complications may include nerve damage or eyelid malposition.(no content)According to one Looksmax discussion, "the risk of complications is around 20% even in good clinics in Europe with proper quality regulations."

## Looksmax Community Perspectives

Some community members argue that "canthoplasty cut a lower eyelid and make an eye smaller" and that certain surgeons' works "are too expensive."(no content)Others note that "most of the canthoplasty 'botches' ain't even botches, it's just people who get it when they already have PCT or they just get a crazy positive rotation."(no content)Many discussions emphasize that canthoplasty is often combined with other procedures like "spacer graft + canthoplasty, or midface lift + canthoplasty, or implant + canthoplasty" to achieve desired results.

Here's a comprehensive overview of rhinoplasty costs in the USA, Turkey, and South Korea, along with revision rates for 2024-2025:

## Rhinoplasty Costs by Country

### United States
- In 2024, the average cost of rhinoplasty in the United States ranged from $6,000 to $15,000, with several key factors influencing this wide price range.
- According to the American Society of Plastic Surgeons, the average base cost for rhinoplasty was $7,637 in 2024, but this figure does not include additional expenses like anesthesia and facility fees, which can add several thousand dollars to the total cost.
- In the United States, rhinoplasty tends to be the most expensive, especially in major cities like Los Angeles or New York. Patients can expect to pay between $12,000 and $24,000, depending on the surgeon's expertise, clinic location, and whether it's a primary or revision procedure.

### Turkey
- Rhinoplasty costs in Turkey range from $2,500-$4,500.
- Turkey has emerged as a global hotspot for affordable and high-quality rhinoplasty. Prices are often bundled into medical tourism packages that include hotel accommodation, airport transfers, and translation services. On average, patients can expect to pay between $6,000 and $8,000.
- Turkey performs around 60,000 rhinoplasty surgeries annually, giving surgeons extensive experience and expertise.

### South Korea
- The cost of rhinoplasty (nose job) in South Korea typically ranges from $3,500 to $5,000. Prices can vary depending on the complexity of the surgery, the surgeon's experience, and whether you need primary or revision rhinoplasty.
- With costs ranging from approximately $2,200 to $7,400 USD, this premier location offers significant savings compared to counterparts in the U.S. or Europe.
- In the United States, the average cost is $16,000 (per ASPS). This means rhinoplasty in South Korea is about 73% less than in the U.S.

## Revision Rhinoplasty Costs

### United States
- Revision rhinoplasty costs in the U.S. typically range from $10,000 to $30,000 or more, with averages often cited around $12,000–$25,000. Complex cases in major cities can exceed $30,000–$35,000.
- Revision rhinoplasty is often more complex and costly, ranging from $9,000 to $20,000.

### Turkey
- In 2025, revision rhinoplasty in Turkey typically ranges from $2,500 to $9,000, offering significant savings compared to the U.S. or Europe.
- In Turkey, the revision rhinoplasty cost ranges from $1,500 to $10,000.

### South Korea
- The cost of revision rhinoplasty in South Korea typically ranges from $4,200 to $7,100. Prices vary depending on the surgeon's experience, the complexity of the revision, and the clinic's location.
- South Korea offers a wide range of prices typically ₩5,500,000 – ₩22,000,000 ($4,000 – $16,000).

## Success/Revision Rates

- Closed rhinoplasty has an 85-90% success rate in achieving desired aesthetic outcomes.
- Revision rhinoplasty in South Korea has an 85% success rate in achieving desired aesthetic and functional outcomes.
- Revision rhinoplasty in Turkey boasts high satisfaction, with reported success rates often cited around 90-95%.

## Key Considerations

- Turkey offers the highest savings (70-80%) while Mexico provides the most convenient access for North American patients.
- In Turkey, medical tourism is popular and comprehensive packages often include accommodations, transfers, and follow-up care. However, patients should exercise caution as the surgical standards and post-operative care can vary widely. It's important to thoroughly research the surgeon's experience and reputation before proceeding.
- South Korean clinics usually include pre-op consultation, surgery, anesthesia, standard implants (if needed), one hospital night, medications, and follow-up visits in the price. In the U.S., the listed price often covers only the surgeon's fee, with separate charges for anesthesia, facility, and aftercare.

Eppley, MD","url":"https://www.eppleyplasticsurgery.com/what-is-the-best-material-for-custom-facial-implants/"},{"title":"What benefits is there to using a PEEK implant for cheek bone/ infra orbital augmentation over the the typical silicone?","url":"https://www.realself.com/question/independence-kansas-benefits-peek-silicon-vice-versa"},{"title":"Insights Into Medpor Facial Implant Removals - Explore Plastic Surgery","url":"https://exploreplasticsurgery.com/insights-into-medpor-facial-implant-removals/"}]

Here's a comprehensive comparison of PEEK, silicone, and Medpor facial implants based on the 2024 research and clinical perspectives:

## Overview of Materials

Facial implantology uses various types of implants including polymers such as silicone, polyethylene (porous polyethylene/Medpor), and others. The most commonly used materials are microporous high-density polyethylene (Medpor) and silicone implants.(no content)A wide range of alloplastic implant materials are used for facial augmentation, of which titanium, porous polyethylene (MedPor), polyether-ether-ketone (PEEK), silicone, and poly-methyl methacrylate (PMMA) are among the most used materials.

## Silicone Implants

**Advantages:**
- Silicone is a flexible material that can be placed through smaller incisions and acquires the feel of bone when the backing on which it rests is bone.
- Silicone has been and will always be a material made for the cosmetic surgery market which has always been cost sensitive.

**Disadvantages:**
- Silicone presents migration, bony resorption, and visibility issues.
- The silicone group had a higher incidence of infections and displacements compared to Medpor in one literature review.

## Medpor (Porous Polyethylene) Implants

**Advantages:**
- Polyethylene, particularly porous polyethylene (MedPor), was reported to have one of the lowest infection rates while it becomes incorporated into the host.
- Medpor complications for similar locations as silicone implants (malar, chin, mandible) showed only 0.7% infections, 5% need for removal or reoperation.
- Medpor gets the most robust tissue ingrowth which occurs due to its surface porosity.

**Disadvantages:**
- Removal of porous implants such as MedPor is much more difficult compared to silicone implants due to the ingrowth of the host's connective tissue.
- Medpor had a rate of 3.9% for undesired prominence (vs. only 1.4% for silicone implants).
- Medpor implant removal becomes the most difficult in the jawline area due to the proximity of nerves and blood vessels, with risk of injury to the sensory mental nerve and motor marginal mandibular nerve.

## PEEK (Polyether-Ether-Ketone) Implants

**Advantages:**
- PEEK is commonly employed for cranial vault reconstruction, spine surgery, and facial augmentation due to its inherent high mechanical strength, low interference with CT/MRI imaging modalities (radiographically translucent), and excellent biocompatibility.
- PEEK is highly resistant to wear and tear, making it a long-lasting solution. Despite being lightweight, PEEK provides excellent structural support.
- Compared to silicone implants, PEEK implants are considered more biocompatible and lower the risk of infection, inflammation, and rejection.

**Disadvantages:**
- A rigid implant like PEEK requires wide open incisional access or, at the least, longer incisions and a much bigger implant pocket.
- Custom designing of a PEEK implant is far more expensive than that of other materials like silicone, often being 2X to 3X more expensive.
- In the U.S. there is a major cost difference between PEEK and silicone for custom implant manufacture. PEEK has its origins in the reconstructive surgery market where costs are considerably higher by a factor of 3X to 4X.

## Key Clinical Considerations

There are a variety of materials for custom facial implants including solid silicone, Omnipore/Medpor, PEEK, PEKK, and titanium—each with their own advantages and disadvantages. To the body, an implant is an implant; no material offers any different or superior biologic benefit. What separates these facial implant materials is not their biologic responses but other features such as cost, design limitations, and ease of placement and revision/removal.(no content)Given that the revision rate of any custom facial implant is in the 40% range, the concept of "easy in, easy out and easy back in" has great clinical merit.(no content)According to one surgeon's perspective, a more rigid material like Medpor may give better results in the jaw, whereas in the midface it probably doesn't matter as much.

Based on my search results, here's what I found about orbital decompression surgery costs:

## Orbital Decompression Surgery Cost

Orbital decompression surgery averages $21,875 per encounter.(no content)Costs vary widely depending on the procedure and complexity. Multiple surgeries may be necessary, and most patients require specialized oculoplastic surgeons, adding to the overall expense.

### Factors Affecting Cost

The cost varies depending on how much decompression is needed and where the surgery is done. Insurance may or may not cover some or all of the costs.(no content)In a hospital setting it will be more expensive than in a free-standing surgery center. The surgery may involve one, two, or three walls of the orbit - the more extensive, the higher the cost.(no content)The cost of orbital decompression surgery varies from one locality to another, and is determined largely by insurance carriers, as it is considered a medical condition.

### About the Procedure

Orbital decompression surgery is performed to relieve exophthalmos, a condition associated with Graves' disease, which causes the eyes to bulge and may lead to loss of vision. Patients typically elect to undergo this procedure when the symptoms of exophthalmos become severe.(no content)The procedure can be performed for functional or rehabilitative reasons, as bulging eyes can cause eye irritation, redness, and tearing from increased exposure of the eyeballs to air and/or an inability to close the eyes fully. Orbital eye socket surgery sets the eyeballs back by removing bone and/or fat from behind the eyeballs through small, hidden or inconspicuous incisions.

### Under Eye Hollowing Note

Relatively hollow area around the eyes can also make the eyeballs appear bulgier.(no content)There are some great non-surgical options too. Fillers, lasers, and microneedling/PRP can improve under eye hollows.

For accurate pricing specific to your situation, it's recommended to consult with an oculoplastic surgeon for an evaluation.

Based on my search results, here's a comprehensive overview of lip lift surgery costs, results, and information about finding surgeons:

## Lip Lift Surgery Cost

The average cost of a lip lift is $3,126 but can range from $2,409 to $6,144, depending on the type of procedure and other factors.(no content)The investment in lip lift surgery ranges from $2,000–$8,000 across the United States, with the national average at $4,535 according to RealSelf patient reports.

### Cost by Location:
- In Beverly Hills, lip lift surgery typically ranges from $4,000 to $10,000, depending on several factors such as the surgeon's expertise, the complexity of the procedure, and additional costs like anesthesia and post-surgical care.
- Typical pricing in New York City for a lip lift ranges from $3,500 to $6,500.
- A Miami lip lift costs $2,000–$6,000 depending on the surgeon.(no content)The national average cost of $3,126 doesn't include costs for anesthesia, the surgery facility and related expenses.(no content)Insurance does not typically cover the cost of a lip lift, because it's considered a cosmetic procedure.

## Results & Worth It Rating

Lip lift surgery earns a solid 90% Worth It Rating from reviewers on RealSelf, so most patients who weighed in say their results were worth the price tag.(no content)A lip lift procedure provides long-lasting lip enhancement with results expected to last up to a decade.(no content)The one-time investment provides permanent results lasting up to a decade. Elimination of recurring filler expenses saves $1,200–$2,400 annually.

## Recovery Timeline

- Initial recovery (Days 1–7) involves expected swelling, bruising, and mild discomfort manageable with over-the-counter medications. Patients should avoid makeup for 10–12 days. Limiting facial movements—including smiling—for two weeks promotes optimal healing.
- Final results from a lip lift surgery are apparent around six weeks.

## Finding a Surgeon

It's well worth the time and expense to find a surgeon with a years-long record of successful outcomes, including before and after photos and glowing patient reviews.(no content)Risks of a lip lift gone wrong include a visible raised scar under the nose, an elongated upper lip or nostrils, a strained smile, or a mouth that moves oddly. These issues could require a second surgical procedure to fix—at additional expense.(no content)When performed by a skilled, board-certified surgeon, most patients achieve natural-looking, fuller lips with improved balance and symmetry.

## Blepharoplasty (Eyelid Surgery): Cost, Recovery, and Complications

Here's a comprehensive overview of blepharoplasty based on current information:

### Cost

The average cost of blepharoplasty in the U.S. is $4,451, but it can vary depending on multiple factors. However, patients should expect to budget around $7,000 to $11,000 for eyelid surgery, encompassing surgeon's fees, facility costs, anesthesia, tests, and follow-up care.

Specific procedure costs vary:
- In San Francisco, upper blepharoplasty costs around $3,000, and a lower blepharoplasty costs around $4,000.
- A lower blepharoplasty surgery will cost from $7,000 to $9,500. An upper blepharoplasty surgery will cost $4,000 to $6,000, and a surgery to address both upper and lower eyelids will cost from $9,000 to $11,000.

**Factors affecting cost:**
- Where the procedure is performed can vary by facility. For example, a hospital or surgical center may tack on extra fees.
- Newly board-certified plastic surgeons may not charge as much as surgeons with extensive experience.
- The anesthesia used during your procedure matters—most doctors perform upper eyelid surgeries using local anesthesia with oral sedation. General anesthesia, if needed, will cost more.

### Insurance Coverage

Most health insurance does not cover cosmetic surgery or its complications. When eyelid surgery is performed to eliminate the redundant skin covering the eyelashes, it may be covered by insurance.(no content)Insurance carriers will only cover the cost of upper eyelid surgery if the patient has an obstruction of their visual field. This must be documented during an examination with formal visual field testing and photographs.

### Recovery

Most people return to normal activities after seven to 10 days following blepharoplasty. By two weeks after eyelid surgery, the majority of the bruising and swelling will resolve.(no content)After blepharoplasty, you will be moved to a recovery room until you are ready to go home. It's normal to have some temporary side effects like blurred vision, watering eyes, light sensitivity, double vision, puffy eyelids, swelling or bruising, and pain and discomfort.(no content)Recovery from blepharoplasty is usually not very painful. Patients may experience mild discomfort, swelling, or bruising in the days following the procedure. These symptoms are temporary and manageable with prescribed medications and proper care.

### Complications and Risks

Opting for a lower-cost surgeon with limited experience in eyelid surgery can lead to unsatisfactory results, functional issues, or complications that require revision surgery. Revision blepharoplasty is significantly more complex and expensive than a primary surgery due to the need for scar tissue correction and delicate reconstruction of the eyelid structure.(no content)Their in-depth understanding of eyelid function, tear production, and eye health makes them uniquely qualified to perform blepharoplasty with both aesthetic and functional precision. Their expertise helps reduce complications, such as dry eyes or eyelid malposition, which can occur when the procedure is performed by a less specialized surgeon.

### Longevity of Results

Blepharoplasty results are long-lasting, with many patients enjoying the benefits for 10 to 15 years or more. Factors such as aging, lifestyle, and genetics can influence how long the results remain noticeable.(no content)The results of blepharoplasty (eyelid surgery) are generally long lasting. The results of upper eyelid surgery will last about five to seven years, and the results of lower eyelid surgery results will last decades.

# V-Line Jaw Surgery in Korea: Cost, Recovery & Best Surgeons (2024)

## Cost Overview

The average cost of V-shape jaw surgery in Korea ranges from $6,000 to $15,000 USD, depending on the surgeon, the clinic, the technique, and the extent of the correction. Another source indicates the typical cost range is 9,900,000 KRW to 15,500,000 KRW (approximately $6,800 to $10,700 USD).(no content)V-line surgery in Korea typically ranges from ₩11,000,000 to ₩18,000,000, depending on the clinic, surgeon's expertise, and complexity of the procedure.

### What's Included in the Cost
The cost usually includes the consultation fee, the anesthesia fee, the hospital fee, the surgery fee, and the post-operative care fee.(no content)However, it may not include the cost of additional procedures, such as chin augmentation, cheekbone reduction, or fat grafting, which can increase the total cost by $2,000 to $5,000 USD each.

### Additional Expenses
The cost may also not include the travel expenses, such as the flight, the accommodation, the transportation, and the food, which can add up to $2,000 to $4,000 USD for a two-week stay.

## Recovery Timeline

Recovery from V-Line Surgery varies among individuals but typically includes a few weeks of swelling and bruising. Patients are advised to follow a soft diet and maintain good oral hygiene during this period. Full results become more apparent as the swelling subsides, usually within three to six months.(no content)Recovery from V-line surgery involves initial swelling and bruising, which is most noticeable in the first 1-2 weeks. Most patients are advised to wear facial compression garments after surgery. After two weeks, most of the major swelling subsides, but residual swelling can last for several months.(no content)You should stay at least 2 to 3 weeks to monitor progress after surgery and remove sutures.(no content)Upon discharge from the hospital after V-Line Jaw Surgery in South Korea, the patients are advised to stay for about 5 days for recovery. This period is important to conduct all the follow-up tests to ensure that the surgery was successful and the patient can go back to the home country.

## Why Korea for V-Line Surgery?

Korea is one of the most popular destinations for V-shape jaw surgery, as it has a large number of experienced and skilled surgeons who specialize in this field. Korea is also known for its advanced technology and high standards of safety and quality in cosmetic surgery.(no content)Choosing South Korea for square jaw surgery offers you unparalleled expertise and advanced techniques that are hard to find elsewhere. Renowned for its facial contouring, South Korea boasts highly qualified surgeons who utilize cutting-edge technology, including 3D imaging for precise planning. You'll appreciate the focus on natural aesthetics, ensuring results that enhance your beauty without looking overly altered.

## Notable Hospitals and Clinics

ID Hospital, located in Seoul, South Korea, is accredited by JCI and is described as the largest facial bone surgery hospital with 5 stories, 2 basement floors, and 30 wards.(no content)Asan Medical Centre, located in Seoul, South Korea, is accredited by ISO.(no content)Some clinics' medical staff have headed departments at renowned institutions like Gangnam Severance Hospital, and consistently demonstrate excellence by providing individualized, scientifically analyzed treatment plans. Each procedure, including V Line and facial contouring surgeries, is performed by seasoned specialists who strive for exceptional results.

## Factors That Influence Cost

The surgeon's reputation, experience, skill, and certification can affect the cost of the surgery. A more reputable and experienced surgeon may charge a higher fee, but may also offer a better quality and result. It is advisable to choose a board-certified plastic surgeon who specializes in facial contouring and has a portfolio of before and after photos of previous patients.(no content)The clinic's location, facilities, equipment, and staff can also affect the cost of the surgery. A more reputable and well-equipped clinic may charge a higher fee, but may also offer a safer and more comfortable environment.

## Potential Risks

Potential risks include nerve damage, asymmetry, excessive bleeding, and infections. However, choosing a highly qualified surgeon and carefully following pre- and post-operative instructions can significantly minimize these risks.(no content)Many clinics also provide translation services for international patients, assistance with travel and accommodation, and detailed aftercare instructions to ensure smooth recovery.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about infraorbital rim implant/tear trough surgery costs, particularly from looksmax discussions in 2024:

## Cost Estimates

From Looksmax.org discussions, users report the cost breakdown as approximately $3k to design and make the custom implant, and about $11k for the surgery itself, totaling around $14-15k.(no content)Another Looksmax discussion mentions costs of $13k to $16k with popular surgeons including Pagnoni. The thread also notes that many patients may need a revision surgery to get the design right, which would be another $13k to $16k, and some recommend planning for 2-3 rounds of fat grafting as well.(no content)Dr. Barry Eppley's website lists an approximate total cost of around $6,500 for the procedure, though this may be for standard (non-custom) implants.

## Procedure Details

A tear trough implant (infraorbital rim implant) is a medical-grade silicone implant that sits along the orbital rim, filling in the hollow space beneath the eye. Using 3D imaging technology, surgeons can create custom implants inserted through a small incision hidden inside the lower eyelid or along the lash line.(no content)Patients with deficiency of the lower orbital rim bone and cheek bone ("congenital maxillary hypoplasia") have appearance of sunken under eye area and may benefit from customized infraorbital rim implants, which help create a more chiseled facial appearance with defined cheekbones.

## Implant Types Discussed on Looksmax

Users discuss custom PEEK infraorbital rim implants with "saddles" - the saddle refers to the area extending to the side of the skull. The saddle design adds more harmony to results, and without sufficient projection on the side, patients can end up with suboptimal outcomes.(no content)Silicone implants are noted to be highly pliable and soft, allowing for easy customization, and are durable, long-lasting, and biocompatible.(no content)PEEK (PolyEtherEtherKetone) implants are known for their strength and rigidity to improve structural support of the infraorbital region.

### Dr. Ramieri
"Ramieri is the 'safe' option in terms of risk/reward... he is also the most transparent and active online."(no content)For bimax, he charges approximately 21-25k euros and "is like the goat of bimax, has ton of results on his ig page and price is good."(no content)"He is not conceited like Raffaini, doesn't promise you the world like Safi, has no known botches like Pagnoni, isn't outrageously priced like Gunson, and doesn't over advance like Alfaro."(no content)Ramieri is considered "a safe middle ground option."

Based on the search results, here's what I found about hardmaxxing surgery complications, nerve damage, and PSL improvement:

## Hardmaxxing Overview

Hardmaxxing includes all the things a person can do to become attractive that involve more invasive approaches. While softmaxxing is about changes to appearance that are not permanent, hardmaxxing almost always involves permanent changes to one's appearance.

## Surgery Complications and Nerve Damage

### Facelift and Facial Bone Surgery
Facelifts produce successful results, but they come with both a lengthy recovery period and possible complications such as nerve damage or scarring.

### Orthognathic Surgery (Jaw Surgery)
Complications were observed in 24 (10.57%) of a total of 227 osteotomies. Among the complications encountered, bleeding (8), nerve damage (7), malocclusion (3), infection (2), TMJ problems (2), bad split (1), and deviation at the tip of the nose (1) stand out.(no content)In a 2008 study by Espeland et al., 508 patients who underwent orthognathic surgery were followed for 3 years, and the rate of patients with ongoing nerve damage is 36%. About 70% of patients over the age of 40 continue to experience numbness, while only 30% of patients under the age of 20 continue to have numbness.

### SARPE/SARME (Maxillary Expansion Surgery)
A 2024 study found complications in the form of postoperative hemorrhage in six patients (10.9%), infraorbital nerve damage (n = 16; 29.1%), dental complications (n = 5; 9.1%), problems with the appliance (n = 3; 5.5%), asymmetric expansion (n = 3; 5.5%), and severe postoperative pain (n = 4; 7.3%).

### Bimax Surgery Concerns
Doing multiple procedures "would probably leave you with some scar tissue and nerve damage etc, that can change how the muscle function and create extremely bad failos in motion. And the risk of infection etc is rather high with that many procedures."

### Bone Smashing Risks
"People who strike their face in the hopes of gaining a chiseled look might be met with nerve damage, airway obstruction, suffocation or blindness… The act can also lead to osteophytes."

## PSL Improvement Expectations

One user reported being 14 months post chin wing surgery, which brought their chin forward 10mm, claiming "definitely + 0.5 PSL or even more."(no content)Many users on surgery forums complain about not getting the ideal "aesthetic" outcome. Moving jaws forward would barely improve PSL for some. Most of the "good" results are of people that already had very good features like phenotype, jaw shape, and eye area.

## Mental Health Concerns

## Hardmaxxing Overview

Hardmaxxing includes all the things a person can do to become attractive that involve more invasive approaches. While softmaxxing is about changes to appearance that are not permanent, hardmaxxing almost always involves permanent changes to one's appearance.

## Surgery Complications and Nerve Damage

### Facelift and Facial Bone Surgery
Facelifts produce successful results, but they come with both a lengthy recovery period and possible complications such as nerve damage or scarring.

### Orthognathic Surgery (Jaw Surgery)
Complications were observed in 24 (10.57%) of a total of 227 osteotomies. Among the complications encountered, bleeding (8), nerve damage (7), malocclusion (3), infection (2), TMJ problems (2), bad split (1), and deviation at the tip of the nose (1) stand out.(no content)In a 2008 study by Espeland et al., 508 patients who underwent orthognathic surgery were followed for 3 years, and the rate of patients with ongoing nerve damage is 36%. About 70% of patients over the age of 40 continue to experience numbness, while only 30% of patients under the age of 20 continue to have numbness.

### SARPE/SARME (Maxillary Expansion Surgery)
A 2024 study found complications in the form of postoperative hemorrhage in six patients (10.9%), infraorbital nerve damage (n = 16; 29.1%), dental complications (n = 5; 9.1%), problems with the appliance (n = 3; 5.5%), asymmetric expansion (n = 3; 5.5%), and severe postoperative pain (n = 4; 7.3%).

### Bimax Surgery Concerns
Doing multiple procedures "would probably leave you with some scar tissue and nerve damage etc, that can change how the muscle function and create extremely bad failos in motion. And the risk of infection etc is rather high with that many procedures."

### Bone Smashing Risks
"People who strike their face in the hopes of gaining a chiseled look might be met with nerve damage, airway obstruction, suffocation or blindness… The act can also lead to osteophytes."

## PSL Improvement Expectations

One user reported being 14 months post chin wing surgery, which brought their chin forward 10mm, claiming "definitely + 0.5 PSL or even more."(no content)Many users on surgery forums complain about not getting the ideal "aesthetic" outcome. Moving jaws forward would barely improve PSL for some. Most of the "good" results are of people that already had very good features like phenotype, jaw shape, and eye area.

## Mental Health Concerns

Based on my search results, here's what I found about Dr. Barry Eppley and custom facial implants:

## Dr. Barry Eppley - Custom Facial Implants Overview

Dr. Barry L. Eppley, MD, DMD is a double-board-certified plastic surgeon specializing in cosmetic procedures for the face, breast and body, with patients in 67 countries around the globe. He is considered the world's foremost authority in the creation of custom implants for the face and body.(no content)His practice is located at 12188-A North Meridian St. Suite 310, Carmel, IN 46032.

### Cost Information

The total cost of a custom jawline implant, including all costs for fabrication and surgical placement, is in the range of $12,000 to $13,000. Note: This pricing information is from an older blog post (2013), so current costs may differ.

One patient inquiry mentioned that a custom chin implant could be up to $9,000 and cheek implants around $15,000, for a potential total of $24,000 when combined.(no content)Dr. Eppley notes that custom facial implants are not significantly more expensive than preformed off-the-shelf implants. While the material cost of the custom implant is higher, they can be surgically placed in half the operative time, so the extra cost to design and fabricate a custom jawline implant is partially offset by the savings of a quicker operation.

### Patient Reviews

One RealSelf reviewer stated: "Dr Eppley is a very skilled and meticulous plastic surgeon. He has passion for his craft."(no content)The same patient noted they "decided that I would rather pay more and get a custom implant, then settle for one off the shelf and risk not being happy with the result" and that "custom implants are the only route to go when for redesigning/enhancing your face. Custom implants are made to fit your bone structure and will allow you to get the exact results you want."(no content)Another patient testimonial stated: "Everything is going well and I am ecstatic at the results. For the first time, I actually have a jawline. It's amazing how much of a difference a few millimeters in the right place can make."

### Procedure Details

A custom jawline implant is fabricated from a patient's 3D CT scan, from which a completely customized implant is made from one jaw angle to the other.(no content)For custom facial implants, the implant designing is done from a 3D CT scan which can be obtained locally and sent to Dr. Eppley - patients do NOT have to travel to his office for the scan. The scan is then used to design the implants online, with patient input during the design process.

**Note:** I couldn't find specific 2024 reviews or updated 2024 pricing in the search results. For current costs and the most up-to-date reviews, I'd recommend contacting Dr. Eppley's office directly or checking RealSelf for more recent patient experiences.

## Bimax Double Jaw Surgery - Before/After and PSL Improvement

### Personal Experience/Results
One user documented their experience with double jaw surgery (bimax) performed in early May 2022 for sleep apnea, covered by insurance, noting that because there are huge aesthetic implications, they shared their results publicly.(no content)At 2 months post-op, most people indicated they had "ascended from incel to low-tier normie," but they noted they were still very swollen, with remaining swelling especially in the cheeks that would dissipate over the next year.(no content)They had a very large advancement and CCW (counter-clockwise) rotation, roughly equivalent to what Dr. Alfaro would have done.

### Suggestions for Additional PSL Improvement
One commenter suggested additional procedures for further PSL improvement: deep necklift by Dr. Nayak ($30-40k), rhino tip elevation plus paranasal implant ($10-15k), and hair system or hair transplant, estimating these could provide a 2 PSL gain.

### Recovery Timeline
Multiple commenters noted that it takes up to 2 years for the face to completely "debloat" after bimax surgery.

### Community Discussion
Some forum members argue that jaw surgery only makes a real difference in cases with significant clinical recession of the jaws, so it won't make a big difference for most people.(no content)Others point out that the average 18 year old doesn't have $30-50k to spend on jaw surgery, and while many recognize it from social media, most never go through with it.

### Medical Perspective
The success rate of bimax surgery is approximately 95%, resulting in improved facial aesthetics and functional outcomes.(no content)Double jaw surgery (bimaxillary osteotomy) involves repositioning both the upper and lower jaws, with most patients achieving full recovery within a year.

Based on my search results, here's comprehensive information about lip filler costs, longevity, and complications:

## Lip Filler Costs

The average cost of lip fillers in the U.S. is $959, but prices can range from $332 up to $2,354 for one treatment.(no content)Juvéderm Ultra or Volbella can cost anywhere from $500 to $1,400 for 1 syringe, while Restylane Silk or Kysse typically costs $500 to $700 for 1 syringe, though some providers charge up to $800.(no content)In 2024, expect to invest $500–$2,000 depending on your goals and location.(no content)Lip fillers are not a one-time expense. Hyaluronic acid fillers typically last 6–12 months, meaning most people require touch-up treatments 1–2 times a year to maintain results. Over five years, this could total $2,500–$10,000 or more.

## Longevity

Standard hyaluronic acid fillers typically last 6-9 months, while premium formulations can extend to 12 months or longer. Thicker gel formulations generally provide longer-lasting results than thinner ones.(no content)Filler longevity varies with the individual: The same product that lasts 12 months in one face can persist for five years in another.

Factors affecting longevity include:
- Metabolism plays a huge role in how long fillers last. If you have a fast metabolism, work out intensively, or are very active, your body may break down the filler more quickly. The constant movement of your lips also contributes to faster breakdown compared to other facial areas.
- Smoking accelerates filler breakdown, sometimes reducing longevity by 30-50%. Sun exposure without protection degrades the filler over time.

## Potential Complications

Lip fillers are generally safe, but there are some potential side effects and risks to be aware of. Side effects are typically mild and temporary. The most common side effects of lip fillers are swelling, bruising and tenderness at the injection sites. Adverse effects happen in less than 1% of lip filler procedures.(no content)Reviewers who say their results were "Not Worth It" typically complained of complications and side effects like asymmetries, lumps, bruising at injection sites, and migration.(no content)Vascular occlusion is a rare but serious complication that occurs when filler is accidentally injected into a blood vessel, leading to blockage. This can cause tissue damage and, in severe cases, necrosis (tissue death) or blindness if the area around the eyes is affected. Immediate medical treatment is required to address this issue.(no content)Unlike lip-filling materials from the past, hyaluronic acid fillers are temporary and can be dissolved with an injection of the enzyme hyaluronidase if there's a complication or you simply don't love your lip enhancement result.

Based on my search results, here's a comprehensive summary of what I found regarding custom zygoma/cheekbone implants:

## Custom Cheekbone/Zygomatic Implants - Key Information

### Surgeons Specializing in Custom Facial Implants

**Dr. Barry Eppley (Indianapolis, IN)**
- Custom facial implants offer remarkable benefits due to the versatility and adaptability of silicone. Their unique design allows Dr. Eppley to place them easily through smaller, discreet oral and facial incisions.
- This is often referred to as the 'high cheekbone look' but anatomically is a more complete coverage of the zygomatic bone that follows its more horizontal course.
- Uses primarily **silicone** for custom implants

**Dr. Michael Yaremchuk (Boston, MA)**
- Dr. Yaremchuk has innovated the use of custom facial implants for both aesthetic and reconstructive indications. Precise measurements obtained from CT scans allow creation of virtual and physical models that allow Dr. Yaremchuk to design implants unique for the patient.
- Dr. Yaremchuk is currently a Clinical Professor of Surgery, Part Time, at the Harvard Medical School, and Chief of Craniofacial Surgery at the Massachusetts General Hospital. He is known as an innovator and teacher who uses state-of-the-art techniques.

### Cost Estimates

**Standard Cheek Implants:**
- The national average cost for a cheek implant procedure with both malar and submalar implants in the United States is $8,795, but it can vary between $6,960 and $15,872 depending on factors such as location, other procedures that might be involved or post-surgery care.
- The average cost of cheek implants (malar augmentation) is $3,876, according to the American Society of Plastic Surgeons. This average cost is only part of the total price – it does not include anesthesia, operating room facilities or other related expenses.

**Custom Implants (Dr. Eppley's pricing):**
- The total cost of such an implant, all costs including fabrication and surgical placement, is in the range of $12,000 to $13,000 for a custom jawline implant
- The cost of this custom facial implant process is $3,500 to $7,500 depending upon how many implants are needed. Surgical placement costs are in addition to the implant fabrication process.

### PEEK Implant Material

PEEK (Polyether Ether Ketone) is a high-performance, biocompatible polymer that has gained popularity for custom facial implants. Custom PEEK implants are designed using advanced 3D imaging, allowing for a precise fit that complements your natural bone structure.(no content)A systematic review identified 32 articles detailing the use of PEEK Patient-Specific Implants (PSIs) in 194 patients for both reconstructive and aesthetic purposes. Complications, including infections and implant failures, were reported in 18% of cases, suggesting the need for improved implant materials.(no content)PEEK is the main material used for the production of the implants and have a long clinical history of more than 20 years of use.(no content)PEEK implants are a biocompatible resin that is made to measure for each patient based on the patient's scanner, and the volume we want to increase. Therefore, they are the most precise and anatomical option that we can offer you today.

### Important Notes
- Specific pricing for custom PEEK cheekbone implants was not found in the search results
- Those looking for an individualized result can have their implants custom-made. Not surprisingly, this option is the most expensive.
- Custom implants typically cost significantly more than standard off-the-shelf implants due to the 3D imaging, design, and fabrication process
- For accurate pricing, direct consultation with surgeons like Dr. Eppley or Dr. Yaremchuk is recommended

content.text:
Now I have comprehensive research data. Let me compile this into a detailed document.

---

# HARDMAXXING SURGICAL PROCEDURES - Complete Research Guide

## Table of Contents
1. [Jaw Surgeries](#1-jaw-surgeries)
2. [Midface Surgeries](#2-midface-surgeries)
3. [Rhinoplasty](#3-rhinoplasty)
4. [Eye Surgeries](#4-eye-surgeries)
5. [Lip Procedures](#5-lip-procedures)
6. [Implant Materials](#6-implant-materials-peek-vs-silicone-vs-medpor)
7. [Top Surgeons](#7-top-surgeons-by-specialty)

---

## 1. JAW SURGERIES

### BSSO (Bilateral Sagittal Split Osteotomy)

**Description:** Lower jaw surgery where the mandible is separated and repositioned forward or backward. Performed entirely inside the mouth (no visible scars).

| Region | Cost Range |
|--------|------------|
| **USA (Manhattan)** | $20,000 - $35,000 |
| **Germany** | ~8,500 EUR |
| **France** | ~3,500 EUR (for full bimax) |
| **Poland** | 4,000 - 5,000 EUR |
| **Italy (Pagnoni, etc.)** | 27,000 - 33,000 EUR |

**Recovery:**
- Swelling peaks at 2-3 days, dramatic
- Most swelling resolves after 2 weeks
- Surgery duration: 2-3 hours
- Hospital stay: 1 night typically
- Full bone healing: 6 weeks to months
- Final soft tissue settling: up to 2 years

**Risk Level:** MEDIUM-HIGH
- Nerve damage (numbness): 36% ongoing at 3 years in one study
- Age-dependent: 70% of patients over 40 have persistent numbness vs 30% under 20

**PSL Improvement:** +0.5 to +1.0 PSL (highly dependent on starting point)

Sources: [myFace BSSO Guide](https://www.myface.org/surgeries/bilateral-sagittal-split-osteotomy/), [Looksmax Bimax Cost Thread](https://looksmax.org/threads/how-much-does-bimax-cost-roughly.675409/), [Manhattan Jaw Surgery Pricing](https://www.parksmilesnyc.com/how-much-does-jaw-surgery-cost-in-manhattan/)

---

### Genioplasty (Sliding Chin Surgery)

**Description:** Chin bone is cut and repositioned (forward, backward, up, down). No implant needed. Permanent results.

| Region | Cost Range |
|--------|------------|
| **USA** | $3,000 - $20,000 |
| **Turkey** | $3,000 - $5,000 (all-inclusive packages) |
| **Korea** | $6,000 - $15,000 (often part of V-line package) |

**Recovery:**
- Major swelling: 10-15 days
- Bone consolidation: 6 weeks
- Final results visible: several months

**Risk Level:** LOW-MEDIUM
- Infection, bruising, asymmetry, numbness

**PSL Improvement:** +0.3 to +0.7 PSL (chin is a key harmony feature)

Sources: [ASPS Chin Surgery Cost](https://www.plasticsurgery.org/cosmetic-procedures/chin-surgery/cost), [Genioplasty Turkey](https://www.themoreclinics.com/genioplasty-chin-augmentation-and-enhancement-types-cost/), [VIP Korea Genioplasty](https://www.vippskorea.com/face/facial-contouring-surgery/genioplasty.html)

---

### Jaw Angle Implants (Standard vs Custom)

**Description:** Implants placed at the mandible angles to create wider, more defined jawline.

| Type | Cost Range |
|------|------------|
| **Standard (off-the-shelf)** | $8,500 - $15,000 total |
| **Custom (3D CT-designed)** | $12,000 - $15,000+ |
| **Three-piece jaw implants** | $8,500 - $9,500 |

**Key Difference:** Custom implants made from 3D CT scan, precisely fitted to bone anatomy. Standard implants are limited in shape customization.

**Recovery:** 2-4 weeks for major swelling, months for final settling

**Risk Level:** MEDIUM
- Migration, infection, nerve damage, asymmetry
- Revision rate: ~40% for custom facial implants overall

**PSL Improvement:** +0.5 to +1.0 PSL

Sources: [Dr. Eppley Custom Implants](https://www.eppleyplasticsurgery.com/what-is-the-cost-of-a-custom-jawline-implant/), [RealSelf Custom Jaw Cost](https://www.realself.com/question/crab-orchard-tn-custom-jaw-chin-implant-cost), [ASPS Facial Implants](https://www.plasticsurgery.org/cosmetic-procedures/facial-implants/cost)

---

### V-Line Surgery (Korea Specialty)

**Description:** Comprehensive jaw reshaping including mandible angle reduction, chin reshaping. Popular for creating slimmer, V-shaped lower face.

| Region | Cost Range |
|--------|------------|
| **Korea** | $6,000 - $15,000 USD |
| **Turkey** | $4,000 - $8,000 USD |
| **UK** | $15,000 - $25,000 USD |

**What's Included:** Consultation, anesthesia, hospital, surgery, post-op care
**NOT Included:** Additional procedures (cheekbone reduction, fat grafting: +$2,000-$5,000 each), Travel ($2,000-$4,000 for 2 weeks)

**Recovery:**
- Major swelling: 1-2 weeks
- Compression garments required
- Full results: 3-6 months
- Recommended stay in Korea: 2-3 weeks

**Risk Level:** MEDIUM-HIGH
- Nerve damage, asymmetry, bleeding, infection

Sources: [AB Plastic Surgery Korea](https://abplasticsurgerykorea.com/ab-blog/v-line-surgery-in-korea-cost-care-and-results), [Korea Clinic Guide V-Line](https://www.koreaclinicguide.com/blog/v-line-surgery-korea), [Dr. MFO V-Line Cost](https://www.dr-mfo.com/v-shape-jaw-surgery/)

---

### Bimax (Double Jaw Surgery / Bimaxillary Osteotomy)

**Description:** Combined upper (Le Fort I) and lower (BSSO) jaw surgery. The "gold standard" for major facial restructuring.

| Region | Cost Range |
|--------|------------|
| **USA** | $35,000 - $45,000+ |
| **Italy (Pagnoni)** | 27,000 - 33,000 EUR |
| **Italy (Ramieri)** | 21,000 - 25,000 EUR |
| **Germany** | ~8,500 EUR |
| **Turkey** | $8,000 - $15,000 |

**Recovery:**
- Hospital: 1-3 nights
- Wired/banded shut: potentially weeks
- Major swelling: 2-4 weeks
- Final debloat: UP TO 2 YEARS
- Return to normal activities: 6-8 weeks

**Risk Level:** HIGH
- Nerve damage: 10-36% long-term
- Bleeding, infection, malocclusion, TMJ problems
- Bad splits possible

**PSL Improvement:** +0.5 to +2.0 PSL (highly case-dependent)
- Works best for clinical jaw recession
- Minimal improvement for already-normal jaws

**RED FLAGS:**
- Surgeons promising unrealistic results
- Not getting 3D planning/VSP
- No orthodontic preparation
- Rushing recovery

Sources: [Healthline Double Jaw Surgery](https://www.healthline.com/health/double-jaw-surgery), [Looksmax Bimax Reality](https://looksmax.org/threads/reality-of-bimax.1252764/), [Looksmax Bimax Before/After](https://looksmax.org/threads/bimax-before-after-4-months-post-op-how-much-did-i-improve.562798/)

---

## 2. MIDFACE SURGERIES

### Le Fort Osteotomies (I, II, III)

**Description:** Upper jaw/midface repositioning surgeries of increasing complexity.

| Type | Description | Recovery |
|------|-------------|----------|
| **Le Fort I** | Upper jaw only | 2-4 weeks swelling, 6 weeks bone healing |
| **Le Fort II** | Midface including nose | 6-8 weeks to normal, months for full healing |
| **Le Fort III** | Complete midface advancement | 8-12 weeks, up to 1 year full recovery |

**Cost:** Typically bundled with bimax ($35,000-$50,000+ in USA)

**Complications:**
- Nasal septum deviation
- Nonunion (bone doesn't heal)
- Malposition
- Hemorrhage
- Avascular necrosis (rare)
- Nerve damage
- Sinus/nasal issues

**Risk Level:** MEDIUM (Le Fort I) to HIGH (Le Fort III)

Sources: [myFace Le Fort I Guide](https://www.myface.org/surgeries/le-fort-1/), [NCBI Le Fort Osteotomy](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK564372/), [Dr. Larry Wolford Le Fort Guide](https://drlarrywolford.com/le-fort-1-osteotomy-a-comprehensive-guide-to-upper-jaw-surgery/)

---

### Cheek Implants (Malar/Submalar)

**Description:** Implants placed on cheekbones (malar) or below cheekbones (submalar) for enhanced projection.

| Type | Average Cost |
|------|--------------|
| **ASPS Average** | $3,876 (surgeon fee only) |
| **Malar only** | $4,453 |
| **Submalar only** | $4,710 |
| **Both (national avg)** | $8,795 |
| **Total with fees** | $6,000 - $15,000 |
| **Custom implants** | $12,000 - $20,000+ |

**Recovery:**
- Swelling: 1-2 weeks major
- Final results: 2-3 months

**Risk Level:** LOW-MEDIUM
- Migration, asymmetry, infection
- Visibility issues (especially with thin skin)

**PSL Improvement:** +0.3 to +0.7 PSL

Sources: [ASPS Cheek Augmentation Cost](https://www.plasticsurgery.org/cosmetic-procedures/cheek-augmentation/cost), [CareCredit Cheek Implant Guide](https://www.carecredit.com/well-u/health-wellness/cheek-implant-cost/), [RealSelf Cheek Implants](https://www.realself.com/surgical/cheek-implants/cost)

---

### Infraorbital Rim Implants (Tear Trough)

**Description:** Implants placed on the lower orbital rim to correct under-eye hollowing and improve cheekbone-to-eye transition.

| Type | Cost Range |
|------|------------|
| **Standard** | ~$6,500 |
| **Custom (with Pagnoni, etc.)** | $13,000 - $16,000 |
| **Design + Surgery** | ~$14,000-$15,000 |

**Key Considerations:**
- Often requires "saddle" extension for harmony
- May need 2-3 rounds of fat grafting
- Revision rate is significant - budget for potential second surgery

**Risk Level:** MEDIUM-HIGH
- Very technical area near eyes
- Implant visibility, asymmetry
- Lower eyelid malposition

Sources: [Looksmax Infraorbital Cost](https://looksmax.org/threads/infraorbital-malar-implants-cost.1117932/), [Dr. Taban Infraorbital Implant](https://tabanmd.com/customized-infraorbital-rim-implant/), [Dr. David Isaacs Tear Trough](https://www.drdavidisaacs.com/eyes-brows/cosmetic-eyelid-surgery/tear-trough-implant-infraorbital-rim-implant/)

---

## 3. RHINOPLASTY

### Primary Rhinoplasty

| Region | Cost Range |
|--------|------------|
| **USA (Average)** | $6,000 - $15,000 |
| **USA (NYC/LA)** | $12,000 - $24,000 |

## 4. EYE SURGERIES

### Canthoplasty (Cat Eye / Fox Eye Surgery)

**Description:** Reshapes the outer corner of the eye (lateral canthus) to create more almond/upturned appearance. Can correct negative canthal tilt (NCT).

| Source | Cost Range |

| **RealSelf Average** | $6,398 |

**Recovery:**
- Major swelling: 1-2 weeks
- Final results: several months
- May require combined procedures for best results

**Risk Level:** MEDIUM-HIGH
- **Complication rate: ~20% even at good European clinics**
- Risk of outer canthus dropping over time
- Scarring, asymmetry, dry eyes

**RED FLAGS:**
- Getting canthoplasty when you already have PCT (positive canthal tilt)
- Expecting it to work alone without supporting procedures
- Canthoplasty can make eyes appear SMALLER

**Common Combinations:**
- Canthoplasty + spacer graft
- Canthoplasty + midface lift
- Canthoplasty + infraorbital implant

### Lip Filler (Hyaluronic Acid)

**Description:** Injectable filler to add volume to lips. Temporary, requires maintenance.

## 6. IMPLANT MATERIALS: PEEK vs SILICONE vs MEDPOR

### Comparison Table

| Property | Silicone | Medpor (Porous Polyethylene) | PEEK |
|----------|----------|------------------------------|------|
| **Cost** | $ (Lowest) | $$ | $$$ (2-4x more) |
| **Rigidity** | Flexible | Semi-rigid | Very rigid |
| **Incision Size** | Small | Medium-Large | Large |
| **Tissue Integration** | None (capsule forms) | High (bone/tissue ingrowth) | Low-Medium |
| **Infection Rate** | Higher (study dependent) | 0.7% | Low |
| **Removal Difficulty** | EASY | VERY DIFFICULT | Medium |
| **Migration Risk** | Higher | Very Low | Low |
| **Visibility Issues** | Higher | Lower | Lower |
| **CT/MRI Interference** | Minimal | Minimal | None (radiographically translucent) |

### Detailed Analysis

**SILICONE**
- Pros: Cheap, flexible, easy to place through small incisions, EASY TO REMOVE/REVISE
- Cons: Migration, bony resorption, higher infection/displacement rates
- Best for: Patients who may want revision, cost-conscious, chin implants

**MEDPOR**
- Pros: Robust tissue ingrowth, very stable, low infection (0.7%), natural integration
- Cons: EXTREMELY DIFFICULT TO REMOVE (nerve damage risk), 3.9% undesired prominence
- Best for: Patients certain about design, jaw area (controversial)
- RED FLAG: Medpor removal near mental/marginal mandibular nerves is high-risk

**PEEK**
- Pros: Biocompatible, strong, lightweight, no CT/MRI interference, long clinical history (20+ years)
- Cons: 2-4x more expensive, requires larger incisions, 18% complication rate in one review
- Best for: Cranial reconstruction, patients wanting premium biocompatibility

### Key Insight
"Given that the revision rate of any custom facial implant is in the 40% range, the concept of 'easy in, easy out and easy back in' has great clinical merit." - This favors **silicone** for aesthetic implants.

Sources: [PMC Facial Implant Materials Review 2024](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10847330/), [Looksmax Silicone vs PEEK](https://looksmax.org/threads/silicone-vs-peek-implants-what-mogs-and-why.105451/), [Dr. Eppley Best Material](https://www.eppleyplasticsurgery.com/what-is-the-best-material-for-custom-facial-implants/), [Explore Plastic Surgery Medpor Removals](https://exploreplasticsurgery.com/insights-into-medpor-facial-implant-removals/)

## COMPLICATIONS SUMMARY

### Nerve Damage Rates by Procedure

| Procedure | Nerve Damage Rate |
|-----------|------------------|
| Orthognathic (all types) | 10.57% immediate, 36% ongoing at 3 years |
| SARPE/SARME | 29.1% infraorbital nerve |
| Age >40 jaw surgery | 70% persistent numbness |
| Age <20 jaw surgery | 30% persistent numbness |
| Canthoplasty | ~20% complication rate |

### General Red Flags

1. **Surgeon has no online presence/portfolio** - can't verify results
2. **Promising unrealistic PSL gains** - "2+ PSL guaranteed"
3. **Not using 3D planning (VSP)** for major bone work
4. **Rushing you into surgery** without proper consultation
5. **No discussion of risks** or complications
6. **Unusually cheap pricing** in Western countries
7. **Multiple unrelated procedures** in single session (infection risk, unpredictable healing)

### Mental Health Warning

"The incessant pressure to conform to narrow beauty standards can lead to the development of serious mental health disorders. Conditions such as depression and anxiety can be exacerbated or triggered by persistent body dissatisfaction."

Sources: [PMC Orthognathic Complications Study](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10442987/), [PMC SARPE Complications 2024](https://pmc.ncbi.nih.gov/articles/PMC11012378/), [ThinkHouse Looksmaxxing Risks](https://www.thinkhousehq.com/the-youth-lab/bone-smashing-looksmaxxing-softmaxxing)

**Critical Note:** "Most of the 'good' results are of people that already had very good features like phenotype, jaw shape, and eye area." Surgery amplifies existing features more than it transforms.
